SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2
PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER Experiences

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer diet
( ) Pioneer schools
( ) Pioneer churches
( ) Pioneer recreation and social life
( ) Pioneer farming experiences
( ) Folklore in Saskatchewan
( ) Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: JOHN F. DAVIES

2. Your address: MEETA, SASK.

3. Date: APRIL 4th

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): MYTON-FORGE MONTFORD BRIDGE, SHROPSHIRE ENGLAND

5. What was your father's name and occupation?: GEORGE DAVIES FARMER

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): JUNE 9th 1904

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: PORTAGE LA PRAIRIE MAN. MAY 1903 TO JUNE 1904

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.): 21 YEARS

9. What were your reasons for coming West?: TO HOMESTEAD, and acquire land.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?): Government pamphlets, distributed in England
PIONEER QUESTIONNAIRE: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name: JOHN E. DAVIES
2. Your address: MEATA, SASK.
3. Date: APRIL 4, 1955
4. Where were you born? (Give names of places and countries): MONTFORD BRIDGE, SHROPSHIRE, ENGLAND.
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: GEORGE DAVIES, FARMER
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): MAY 1903
7. How many other places have you lived before coming to Saskatchewan? (Give dates wherever possible): PORTAGE LA PRAIRIE, MAN., JUNE 1904
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use *I was*):
   *I was in my twenties*, etc.
9. What were your reasons for coming West? TO HOMESTEAD, and acquire land.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people?, Reading about it?, Railroads or government information?): Government pamphlets distributed in England.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   - Slight projections at first, but favorable before leaving.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   - Another friend intended coming with me but backed out at the last minute.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   - By steamship "Grampian" and Railroad

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
   - A very pleasant voyage. Lots of excitement. Expectations of a new country, and fully thought the C.P.R. owned Canada.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   - Landed in Saskatoon, and pitched our tent on the site now occupied by St. Paul's Hospital, Saskatoon.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   - Sec. 6, 47-18 W., 3rd mer.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   - Meota Park.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
   - Miller by trade, and worked for a very small wage, which determined me to make the move to Canada.
   - In Canada farmed until on the above land until 1947, retired from there.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

13. What means of transportation did you use?

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

By Alexander "Graham" and Ruland

Freely shipped to C.P.R. Canada
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   Very seldom, perhaps twice a year.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.
   Remained a bachelor.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle? No.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
   Big Prairie Fire in February 1905, just missed being burned out. Worked over, which didn't appeal and got rid of them as soon as possible, and exchanged for horses.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
   Dances, church services, held in various homes in the district; visiting neighbors occasionally few and far between. While at a dance, came home the next a.m. to find the house and all belonging burned to the ground.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? No

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came west tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

Big Prairie fire - February 1905. Just missed being burned out. Turned away, which did it a good deal of harm as soon as possible, and saved you for Lorne.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of transportation?

Lorne's church services held in various towns in the district; visiting neighbors occasionally you and family. While at a dance, came home the next morning to find the platform and all belongings buried to the ground.
25. When was the first car used in the community? 1910 International Chain drive

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Old Meota store. Owned by J.P. Dart. 13 miles away.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   Until 1911. The C.N.R. townsite at the present Meota four miles from the old Meota J.P. Dart building at the new townsite, and still operated by the late J.P. Dart's eldest son John. Shipped by horseback, wagon & buggy.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   Once a fortnight.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays? About 1916.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   Being a bachelor, could get all my seeds at the above local store.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   Bell Telephone Co. 1920

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   Yes. Perfectly satisfied from the beginning. Continued to farm until the spring of 1947. Sold out, live at the Meota Hotel for the summer, and leave for Victoria in the fall each year and return to Meota about the end of May each year.
25. When was the first car used in the community? 1910

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)

Until 1911 the C.N.R. locomotive at the present site of four miles from the nearest railway station. The building still stands today.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?

Once a fortnight.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays? About 1916

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what proportion of your total purchases were by mail order.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan, the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

Yes. Perfectly satisfied from the beginning.

Continued to farm until the fall of 1917.

Sold out my store at the North Hotel for the summer, and came to Victoria in the fall of each year and returned to the store about the end of May each year.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

A family from Detroit came in to Longview, and on proving up, sold their land and returned to Detroit, which was their primary intention.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

No. It was never a dried out area. Dry enough at times, but managed to get by.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Theota (an Indian name meaning good farming ground)

If someone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person sign and return here:

[Signature]

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1940? What reasons did they have for moving?

A family from Oklahoma moved to our community, and on purchasing land and their permanent residence.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? If so, why?

No. It was during a period of economic depression, but many moved because of the lack of jobs.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organization, mention it here by giving dates whenever possible.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were active in the district section at the time of the first automobile, mention it here.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, townships, stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name; (2) origin and meaning of the name; (3) date of the adoption or change; (4) any changes in names since the first name was given; date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as shown in (1), (2), (3).

Note: An Indiana name meaning anything grows.

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

Good roads, cars, telephone, the railroad coming in.

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

Good work, dear, well done, the railroad coming in.
